text: the brightest stars in the night sky are
in fact planets in our solar system
Venus often shines brightly at other
times it's Mars with its reddish tinge
and sometimes Jupiter can be seen high
above the trees in the center but this
week the three came together in the
skies they become visible at dawn
for an hour or so before the sun's rays
washes them away this time-lapse from
Bay Fabri observatory and hartfordshire
shows them floating across the sky like
some celestial triangle you have to get
up around 4:30 5 o'clock in the morning
a get out of bed look due east and
you'll see three planets in the sky
close together Mars Venus and Jupiter if
you've got a pair of binoculars it's
even better because you not only do you
have these three bright planets but you
can see things like the moon's going
around Jupiter as well it's a fantastic
sight so how does all this happen every
few years the orbits of some of the
planets align it doesn't last long
this series of images show Mars Jupiter
and Venus coming together next week
they'll go their separate ways the next
time something like this will happen
again will be in January 2021 Pollard
Ghosh BBC news
